<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
{
	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	if (enable ==  METAL_IRQ_ENABLE) {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
	} else {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expression in the provided function is invariant. The first if uses irq, cntr->irq_base and cntr->irq_num (all inputs/state that can vary). The second if compares the parameter enable against METAL_IRQ_ENABLE — enable is a function parameter and thus not a compile-time invariant. There are no loops with constant conditions (no infinite loops or do-while with integer constant expressions). The atomic_store calls are not control statements. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 in the supplied code.
